steps.title: Eat 6 small meals a day so your stomach doesn’t get too full.
steps.content: Eat 6 small meals a day so your stomach doesn’t get too full. If your stomach is too full, the food might flow out of your stomach and into your esophagus. This can further damage your esophagus. To help your esophagus heal, shrink the size of your meals. Rather than eating 3 big meals, eat 6 snack-size meals about every 2-3 hours. [1] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Smaller meals are less likely to cause acid reflux. This gives your esophagus time to heal.

steps.title: Eliminate your trigger foods from your diet.
steps.content: Eliminate your trigger foods from your diet. Keep a food diary to figure out which foods trigger your acid reflux. Then, cut these foods from your diet. This might reduce your acid reflux so your esophagus can heal. Common triggers include the following: [2] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Caffeine Spicy foods Fatty foods Mint-flavored foods Chocolate Tomatoes Citrus Onions Garlic Coffee Tea Soda

steps.title: Eat a high fiber diet so stomach empties faster.
steps.content: Eat a high fiber diet so stomach empties faster. Fiber improves your digestive process, so a high fiber diet may help you manage your stomach acid production. Make sure you eat enough fiber to meet your daily dietary recommendations. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Consume at least 25 g of fiber daily if you’re a woman or 38 g of fiber daily if you’re a man. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source High fiber foods include vegetables, fruits, nuts, seeds, beans, legumes, and whole grains. For example, you could include a daily serving of sunflower seeds, pumpkin seeds, chia seeds, flax seed, or almonds to boost your fiber intake.

steps.title: Consume more probiotics to help your stomach digest food faster.
steps.content: Consume more probiotics to help your stomach digest food faster. Probiotics support healthy gut bacteria, which supports a healthy digestive system. To increase your probiotics, eat yogurt with live active cultures and fermented foods, such as kimchi, sauerkraut, miso, tempeh, and kombucha. This might reduce your incidence of acid reflux. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You can also find over-the-counter probiotic supplements. Check with your doctor to find out if they’re right for you.

steps.title: Stop drinking alcohol
steps.content: Stop drinking alcohol because it may cause acid reflux. Alcohol relaxes your esophageal sphincter, which is a muscular ring that closes your esophagus. Normally, your esophageal sphincter prevents your stomach contents from rising up into your esophagus. Since alcohol relaxes your sphincter, it may trigger acid reflux. Eliminate alcohol from your diet to allow your esophagus to heal. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you don’t want to stop drinking, you might limit yourself to 1 drink a day. Additionally, don’t drink within 2 hours before bed because your stomach acid may flow up while you’re sleeping.

steps.title: Maintain a healthy weight to reduce your risk for acid reflux.
steps.content: Maintain a healthy weight to reduce your risk for acid reflux. When you’re carrying excess body weight, it may apply pressure to your esophageal sphincter. This may open your esophageal sphincter, allowing your stomach acid to escape and damage your esophagus. Talk to your doctor to find out your optimal target weight. Then, change your diet and increase your activity to help you reach and maintain your healthy weight. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Don’t assume you need to lose weight without talking to your doctor. Similarly, don’t make diet or exercise changes without checking with your doctor to make sure they’re safe for you.

steps.title: Take pills with a full glass of water so they don’t lodge in your throat.
steps.content: Take pills with a full glass of water so they don’t lodge in your throat. Pills may get stuck in your throat, which can irritate your esophagus. To prevent this, drink a full glass of water every time you take a pill to wash it down. This might protect your esophagus. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you’re taking more than 1 pill, swallow them 1 at a time to make it easier for them to go down. However, you don’t need to drink more than 1 full glass of water.

steps.title: Stop eating 3 hours before you go to bed.
steps.content: Stop eating 3 hours before you go to bed. After you eat, it takes a few hours for your body to digest your food. If you lie down during this time, your stomach contents and stomach acid may flow up into your esophagus. Avoid eating late night meals and snacks so you don’t go to bed on a full stomach. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It also helps to prop yourself up on pillows or elevate the head of your bed so that your food and stomach acid flow downwards. This may prevent it from damaging your esophagus.

steps.title: Wait 2-3 hours after a meal to engage in vigorous exercise.
steps.content: Wait 2-3 hours after a meal to engage in vigorous exercise. While it’s okay to take a walk after you eat, intense exercise may push stomach acid up into your esophagus. To prevent further esophageal damage, allow your food to digest for at least 2-3 hours before you work out. This may help you avoid acid reflux so your esophagus can heal. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source For instance, you might exercise 2 hours after your afternoon meal, just before dinner. Similarly, you might work out in the morning before you eat breakfast.

steps.title: Chew gum to increase saliva production, which neutralizes acid.
steps.content: Chew gum to increase saliva production, which neutralizes acid. When you chew gum, your mouth naturally produces more saliva. Because saliva neutralizes stomach acid, chewing gum may help your esophagus heal. Chew a piece of gum after a meal or when you’re experiencing heartburn. [11] X Research source Since minty flavors might trigger acid production, pick flavors other than mint.

steps.title: Quit smoking
steps.content: Quit smoking to avoid drying out your esophagus. You probably already know that smoking harms your health, but cigarette smoke dries out your esophagus and damages your blood vessels. Smoking also relaxes your esophageal sphincter, which allows your stomach acid to flow up into your esophagus. Quitting is extremely difficult, so talk to your doctor about quitting aids to help you cut out cigarettes for good. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Your doctor may prescribe you patches, lozenges, gum, acupuncture, and prescription medication to help you quit.

steps.title: Take an herbal acid reflux remedy if your doctor says it’s okay.
steps.content: Take an herbal acid reflux remedy if your doctor says it’s okay. Herbal treatments for acid reflux include licorice, chamomile, slippery elm, and marshmallow. Purchase capsules or tablets from your local drug store, a health food store, or online. After checking with your doctor, use your herbal treatment as directed on the label. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Don’t take an herbal remedy without talking to your doctor, as they can interfere with certain medications. Additionally, ask your doctor to recommend the proper dosage for you. Be aware that licorice can raise blood pressure if taken in high doses over the long-term. If you do decide to try licorice, opt for a supplement labeled as deglycyrrhizinated, also known as DGL, such as rhizinate chewable DGL.

steps.title: Use relaxation techniques to help prevent acid reflux.
steps.content: Use relaxation techniques to help prevent acid reflux. Unfortunately, stress may trigger acid reflux, so it’s important to manage your stress levels. To help you keep stress in check, incorporate stress relievers into your daily. Here are some relaxation techniques to try: [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Meditate for at least 10 minutes. Perform progressive muscle relaxation . Try guided imagery meditation. Write in a journal . Talk to a friend about your problems.

steps.title: Try acupuncture to possibly get heartburn relief.
steps.content: Try acupuncture to possibly get heartburn relief. While there’s little evidence that it works, you might get heartburn relief from acupuncture. During acupuncture, a licenced acupuncturist inserts tiny needles into your skin to provide a health benefit, such as reduced acid reflux. This may allow your esophagus to heal. Talk to an acupuncturist to find out if the treatment might help you. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Some people find that acupuncture improves their heartburn, but it doesn’t work the same way for everyone. Acupuncture typically isn’t painful but you might experience some discomfort. It’s best to check with your doctor before getting acupuncture.

steps.title: Use over-the-counter antacids to control stomach acid.
steps.content: Use over-the-counter antacids to control stomach acid. You might be able to decrease stomach acid damage by taking antacids that are available in drug stores. Antacids neutralize stomach acid so it can’t trigger heartburn. Read the label and take your antacids as directed. Use them as needed to relieve your heartburn. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Check with your doctor before using antacids.

steps.title: Check with your doctor before trying natural treatments.
steps.content: Check with your doctor before trying natural treatments. While natural treatments are generally safe, they aren’t right for everyone. They may worsen certain medical conditions and may interact with certain treatments. Talk to your doctor to find out if natural treatments are right for you. [17] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Tell your doctor that you’re hoping to heal your esophagus. They may have natural treatment options they can recommend.

steps.title: Get an official diagnosis for your underlying condition.
steps.content: Get an official diagnosis for your underlying condition. There are several different causes for esophageal damage, so it’s important to get a proper diagnosis. The correct treatment for you depends on what’s damaging your esophagus. [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Visit your doctor to get a barium X-ray, endoscopy, and lab tests on tissues collected from your esophagus. Then, talk to them about your diagnosis and treatment plan. [19] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source During a barium X-ray, your doctor will have you drink a barium compound that will show up on an X-ray. Then, they’ll take a series of X-rays to see your esophagus and look for issues. This text is totally painless. For an endoscopy, your doctor will insert a tiny camera and light down your throat. You might be partially sedated during the test so you’re comfortable. They might collect tissue samples during this test.

steps.title: Ask your doctor if medications may be damaging your esophagus.
steps.content: Ask your doctor if medications may be damaging your esophagus. Some medications may irritate your esophagus and prevent it from healing. Don’t stop taking any medications without checking with your doctor. However, ask your doctor if you might be able to try a different treatment. Here are some medications that might irritate your esophagus: [20] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Anti-inflammatory painkillers Tricyclic antidepressants Postmenopausal estrogen Alendronate (Fosamax) Ibandronate (Boniva) Risedronate (Actonel)
